metadata.title: Characterizing geographical and temporal dynamics of novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 using informative subtype markers

abstract.text: We propose an efficient framework for genetic subtyping of a pandemic virus and implement it for SARS-CoV-2, the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19. Efficient viral subtyping can be a a critical tool to visualize and model, in real-time, the geographic distribution and temporal dynamics of disease spread.

Specifically, effective containment strategies and potential future therapeutic and vaccine strategies will rely on precise and quantitative understanding of SARS-CoV-2 transmission and evolution. In this paper, we utilize an entropy-based analysis to identify mutational signatures of SARS-CoV-2 sequences in the GISAID database available as of April 5, 2020. Our subtyping method identifies nucleotide sites within the viral genome which are highly informative of variation between the viral genomes sequenced in different individuals.

These sites are used to characterize individual virus sequence with a characteristic Informative Subtype Marker (ISM). The ISMs provide signatures that can be efficiently and rapidly utilized to quantitatively trace viral dynamics through geography and time. We show that by analyzing the ISM of currently available SARS-CoV-2 sequences, we are able to profile international and interregional differences in viral subtype, and visualize the emergence of viral subtypes in different countries over time. To validate and demonstrate : bioRxiv preprint the utility of ISM-based subtyping: (1) We show the distinct genetic subtypes of European infections, in which early on infections are related to the viral subtypes that has become dominant in Italy followed by the development of local subtypes, (2) We distinguish subtypes associated with outbreaks in distinct parts of the United States, identify the development of a local subtype potentially due to community to transmission and distinguish it from the predominant subtype in New York, suggesting that the outbreak in New York is linked to imported cases from Europe. (3) We present results that quantitatively show the temporal behavior of the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 from localization in China to a pattern of distinct regional subtypes as the virus spreads throughout the world over time. Accordingly, we show that genetic subtyping using entropy-based ISMs can play an important complementary role to phylogenetic tree-based analysis, such as the Nextstrain [10] project, in efficiently quantifying SARS-CoV-2 dynamics to enable modeling, data-mining, and machine learning tools. Following from this initial study, we have developed a pipeline to dynamically generate ISMs for newly added SARS-CoV-2 sequences and generate updated visualization of geographical and temporal dynamics, and made it available on Github at https://github.com/EESI/ISM. 2

body_text.text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the novel coronavirus responsible for the achieve important goals for understanding the progression of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as ultimately 50 contain and resolve the disease. Exemplary potential applications of quantitative subtyping include: 51 • Characterizing potentially emerging variants of the virus in different regions, which may ultimately 52 express different phenotypes. 53 • Monitoring variation in the viral genome that may be important for vaccine, for example due to 54 emerging structural differences in proteins encoded by different strains. 55 • Designing future testing methodology to contain disease transmission across countries and regions, for 56 example developing specific tests that can characterize whether a COVID-19 patient developed 57 symptoms due to importation or likely domestic community transmission. 58 • Identifying viral subtypes that may correlate with different clinical outcomes and treatment response in 59 different regions (and potentially even patient subpopulations). 60 In this paper, we propose a method to define a signature for the viral genome that can be 1) utilized to 61 define viral subtypes that can be quantified, and 2) efficiently implemented and visualized. In particular, to 62 satisfy the latter need, we propose compressing the full viral genome to generate a small number of 63 nucleotides that are highly informative of the way in which the viral genome dynamically changes. Based on 64 such a signature, SARS-CoV-2 subtypes may thus be defined and then quantitatively characterized in terms 65 of their geographic abundance, as well as their abundance in time -and, potentially also detect clinical 66 variation in disease progression associated with viral subtypes. We propose and develop a pipeline to utilize 67 entropy to identify highly informative nucleotide positions, and, in turn, identifying characteristic 68 Informative Subtype Markers (ISM) that can be used to subtype individual SARS-CoV-2 virus genomes. We 69 evaluate the pipeline by demonstrating the potential of ISMs to model and visualize the geographic and 70 temporal patterns of the SARS-CoV-2 using sequences that are currently publicly available from the GISAID 71 database. We have made the pipeline available on Github https://github.com/EESI/ISM, where it will be 72 continuously updated as new sequences are uploaded to data repositories. The latest report by Apirl 10, 2020 73 can be found in https://github.com/EESI/ISM/blob/master/ISM-report_20200405.ipynb.

Data collection and preprocessing 76 SARS-CoV-2 (novel coronavirus) sequence data was downloaded from GISAID (http://www.gisaid.org) on 77 April 5, 2020 which contains 4087 sequences. The preprocessing pipeline then begins by filtering out 78 sequences that are less than 25000 base pairs (the same threshold used in Nextstrain project built for 79 SARS-CoV-2 1 ). We also included a reference sequence from National Center for Biotechnology Information 2 80 (NCBI Accession number: NC 045512.2). This resulted in an overall data set of 3982 sequences with 81 sequence length ranging from 25342 nt to 30355 nt. We then align all remaining sequences after filtering 82 together using MAFFT [14] using the "FFT-NS-2" method in XSEDE [32] . After alignment, the sequence 83 length is extended (for the present data set, up to 35362 nt). For the aligned sequences, we merged the sequence with the metadata in Nextstrain project 3 as it is in April 6, 2020 based on identification number, gisaid epi isl, provided by GISAID [26] . We further filtered out sequences with incomplete date information in metadata (e.g, "2020-01"), so that our analysis can also incorporate temporal information with daily resolution, given the fast-moving nature of the pandemic. In addition, we filtered out sequences from unknown host or non-human hosts. The resultant final dataset contains 3832 sequences excluding the reference sequence. Then, we calculate the entropy by:

H "´ÿ kPL p k˚l og 2 pp k q where L is a list of unique characters in all sequences and p k is a probability of a character k. We estimated 86 p k from the frequency of characters. We refer to characters in the preceding because, in addition to the bases 87 a, c, g, and t, the sequences include additional characters representing gaps and ambiguities: -, b, d, h, k, m, 88 n, r, s, v, w, and y. (Note that the sequences are of cDNA derived from viral RNA, so there is a t 89 substituting for the u that would appear in the viral RNA sequence.) However, sites n and -(representing an 90 ambiguous site and a gap respectively) are less informative. Therefore, we further define a masked entropy as 91 entropy calculated without considering sequences containing n andin a given nucleotide position in the 92 genome. Based on the entropy calculation, we developed a masked entropy calculation whereby we ignore the 93 n and -. With the help of this masked entropy calculation, we can focus on truly informative positions, 94 instead of positions at the start and end of the sequence in which there is substantial uncertainty due to 95 artifacts in the sequencing process. Finally, high entropy positions are selected by two criteria: 1) entropy 96 ą 0.5, and 2) the percentage of n andis less than 25%. This yielded 17 distinct positions along the viral 97 genome sequence. We then extract Informative Subtype Markers (ISMs) at these 17 nucleotide positions 98 from each sequence. Figure 1 shows how we identified these two criteria. The left hand side of the plot shows 99 that there is a peak with entropy greater than 0.5, which we sought to retain. Looking to the right hand side 100 of the plot, setting threshold to 0.25 will keep the peak on the left which represents the most informative 101 group of sites in the genome.

Quantification and visualization of viral subtypes 103 At the highest level, we assess the geographic distribution of SARS-CoV-2 subtypes, and, in turn, we count 104 the frequency of unique ISMs per location and build charts and tables to visualize the ISMs, including the 105 pie charts, graphs, and tables shown in this paper. All visualization in this paper and our pipeline are 106 generated using Matplotlib [11] . To improve visualization, ISMs with frequency less than 5% in a given 107 location are collapsed into "OTHER" category per location. Our pipeline then creates pie charts for different 108 locations to show the geographical distribution of subtypes. Each subtype is also labeled with the earliest 109 date associated with sequences from a given location in the dataset. 110 To study the progression of SARS-CoV-2 viral subtypes in the time domain, we group all sequences in a given location that were obtained no later than a certain date (as provided in the sequence metadata) together and compute the relative abundance (i.e., frequency) of corresponding subtypes. Any subtypes with a relative abundance that never goes above 2.5% for any date are collapsed into "OTHER" category per 6/32 location. The following formula illustrates this calculation:

where ISM ps,cq ptq is the relative abundance of a subtype, s, in location, c, at a date t, N s,c ptq is the total 111 number of instances of such subtype, s, in location, c, that has been sequenced no later than date t and 112 N c ptq is the total number of sequences in location, c, that has been sequenced no later than date t. 113 We also include a proof of concept for using hierarchical clustering to organize ISM subtypes. We picked 114 the 50 most abundant ISMs and calculated the pairwise hamming distance between them [12] . We then 115 performed hierarchical clustering on these ISMs based on the Hamming distances using average linkage 116 (specifically utilizing the UPGMA algorithm) [20] . The hierarchical clusters are then visualized in a tree 117 format, as shown below in Figure 16 . The leaves in Figure 16 Importantly, even though the combinatorial space for potential ISMs is potentially very large due to the 131 large number of characters that may present at any one nucleotide position, only certain ISMs occur in 132 significantly large numbers in the overall sequence population. Figure 3 shows the rapid decay in the 133 frequency of sequences with a given ISM, and shows that only the first nine ISMs represent subtypes that are 134 significantly represented in the sequences available worldwide. event. An example of this is the number of sequences from cruise vessels in the database. We expect that the 142 impact of any such clustering will be diminished in time as more comprehensive sequencing efforts take place. 143 there would be high selection pressure (i.e., due to exposure to the human immune response or need to gain 149 entry to host cells).

After the informative nucleotide positions were identified, we then mapped those sites back to the 151 annotated reference sequence for functional interpretation [34] . As shown in Table 1 , we found that all but 152 one of the nucleotide positions that we identified were located in coding regions of the reference sequence.

The majority of the remaining sites (9/16) were found in the ORF1ab polyprotein, which encodes a 154 polyprotein replicase complex that is cleaved to form nonstructural proteins that are used as RNA 155 polymerase (i.e., synthesis) machinery [15] . One site is located in the reading frame encoding the S spike 156 glycoprotein, which is responsible for viral entry and antigenicity, and thus represents an important target for 157

. CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint understanding the immune response, identifying antiviral therapeutics, and vaccine design [21, 33] . 158 High-entropy nucleotide positions were also found in the nucleocapsid formation protein, which is important 159 for packaging the viral RNA. [38] A study has also shown that, like the spike protein, the internal 160 nucleoprotein of the virus is significant in modulating the antibody response. [31] 161 Additionally, Table 1 shows a high-entropy, informative site in the predicted coding region ORF8. Based 162 on structural homology analysis the ORF8 region in SARS-CoV-2 does not have a known functional domain 163 or motif [4] . In previously characterized human SARS coronavirus, ORF8 has been associated with an 164 enhanced inflammatory response, but that sequence feature does not appear to have been conserved in 165 SARS-CoV-2, and, in general, SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 appears divergent from other previously characterized 166 SARS-related coronaviruses [4, 39] . Previous entropy-based analysis of earlier and smaller SARS-CoV-2 167 sequence data sets have suggested that there is a mutational hotspot in ORF8, including early divergence 168 between sequences found in China, and large scale deletions found in patients in Singapore -which is 169 consistent with the results we have found here on a much more comprehensive analysis of genomes [3, 27, 29] . 170 Similarly, sites were identified in the ORF3a reading frame, which also appears to have diverged 171 substantially from other SARS-related viruses. In particular, the SARS-CoV-2 variant in the predicted 172 ORF3 region appear also to not contain functional domains that were responsible for increased inflammatory 173 response as they were in those viruses [4, 39] .

While the significance of ORF8 to viral biology and clinical outcomes remains uncertain, the majority of 175 high-entropy sites are in regions of the genome that may be significant for disease progression and the design 176 of vaccines and therapeutics. Accordingly, ISMs derived from the corresponding nucleotide positions can be 177 used for viral subtyping for clinical applications, such as identifying variants with different therapeutic 178 responses or patient outcomes, or for tracking variation that may reduce the effectiveness of potential vaccine 179 candidates. though, Japan includes a number of sequences, of a subtype that is found extensively in European countries, 213 TCTCGTCCACGGGTAAC, first found in Japan on March 11, 2020 . This subtype has also been found in Canada 214

and Brazil, suggesting a geographical commonality between cases in these diverse countries with the 215 progression of the virus in Europe. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint from France, TCTCGTCCACGTGTGGG, is also found in neighboring Belgium, but it is not a prevalent subtype in 220 other European countries shown in Figure 4 . Indeed, this subtype was found in 0.06% of sequences in the 221 United Kingdom, and in only one sequence in Iceland, which has the largest per capita sample size in the 222 data set (see Supplementary file 1 -ISM abundance table of 16 countries/regions). The subtype is found, 223 however, in other countries like Canada, Australia, and Japan, suggesting a potential viral transmission due 224 specifically to travel between France and those two countries. We also found that different states within the United States have substantially different subtype 226 distributions. Figure 5 shows the predominant subtype distributions in the states with the most available 227
sequences. Figure 5 also shows the subtypes found among U.S. passengers on the Diamond Princess cruise, 228

which experienced an outbreak that was traced back to a Hong Kong passenger who embarked on the vessel 229 on January 21, 2020. [23] . The pie charts demonstrate subregional viral subtype diversity within the United 230

States. The colors shown on the charts are also keyed to the colors used in Figure 4 , which allows for the The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint States, by contrast, the patterns of viral subtypes are distinctly different.

Most prominently, the sequences in New York are dominated a subtype, TTTCGTCCACGTGTGGG, which is 237 also highly abundant among sequences from European countries, including France, Iceland, Germany, and 238 Belgium. California, on the other hand, includes as a dominant subtype, CCCCGCCCACAGGTGGG, which is also 239 a major subtype in Mainland China, as shown in Figure 4 . The most abundant subtype in Washington, The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint distribution of the dominant subtypes in Italy. Based on publicly available sequence data from Italy, we 254 found that Italy had two particularly abundant ISMs, TCGTCCACGGGTAAC and TCGTCCACGGGTGGG, as can be 255 seen in the pie chart in Figure 4 . (The third-most abundant subtype shown in the chart 256 (CCCCTCCCACAGGTGGG) corresponds to cases that were linked to original exposure from China, which is 257 consistent with the ISM being in common with one found in Mainland China.) Figure 6 shows the relative 258 abundance (proportion of total sequences in that country/region) of each of these two "Italy subtypes" in 259 other countries/regions. As the plot shows, the outbreak in other European countries have generally involved 260 the same viral subtypes as those which are most abundant in Italy, as defined by ISM. Indeed, initial reports 261 of cases in various other European countries in late February 2020 were linked to travellers from Italy [1].
The Italy subtypes are found, however, at lower yet still significant abundance in countries including Japan, 263
Canada, the United States, and Australia. in New York (TTTCGTCCACGTGTGGG) was detected in one sequence in Iceland linked to exposure in Italy.

However, that same subtype was found in Iceland in sequences from 27 cases linked to exposure in Austria, 2 272 from Denmark, and 1 from Germany. This further suggests that it was unlikely that the incidence of the 273 TTTCGTCCACGTGTGGG subtype in New York is connected to Italy rather than elsewhere in Europe, but limited 274 sequence coverage prevents more definitive inference.

The Italy subtypes are not found at all in locations in Asia, however, such as Mainland China and 276 Singapore, as indicated in Figure 6 . An additional observation to note from 6 is that the most abundant Italy is linked to potential exposure from another country in Europe. Overall, the foregoing results are 283 consistent with phylogenetic tree-based analyses, such as that illustrated on NextStrain's website 284 (http://www.nextstrain.org/ncov), which suggest a flow of the infection from Asia, to Italy, and then subsequently export from Italy to other countries in Europe. It is important to note, however, that the ISMs 286 also resolve potentially significant differences in the subtype distributions in European countries outside of 287 Italy as the virus continues to progress, indicated in Figure 4 . Figure 13 . Relative abundance of ISMs in DNA sequences from Spain as sampled over time.

It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint subtypes are emerging and growing over time, by plotting the relative abundance of viral subtypes in a 304 country/region (via the most frequently occurring ISMs over time), in Figs. 7-13. As discussed above, 305 through the pipeline we have developed, these plots use a consistent set of colors to indicate different ISMs 306 (and are also consistent with the coloring scheme in Figure 4 ). as well as COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths [30] . As discussed above, the predominant subtype in New 336 York (TTTCGTCCACGTGTGGG) is in fact the same as a major subtype found in European countries. such as 337 France, suggesting a link between the New York outbreak and Europe, to a link to the putative endogenous 338 subtype in the United States (CCCCGCCCACAGTTGGG). The plots in Figure 8 further shows that the putative 339 endogenous U.S. subtype was expanding prior to the first detection of the New York major subtype, further 340 supporting the theory that New York's outbreak is not linked to the dominant subtype elsewhere in the 341 United States, particularly Washington state (see Figure 5 ).

As shown in Figures Figs. 11-13 , the subtype distribution in sequences in European countries differs 343 significantly from that of North America and Australia. In particular, as detailed above, the European 344 dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 appear to reflect the theory that in many European countries, the first cases were 345 due to travel from Italy. In data from the United Kingdom, however, we observe the same initial subtypes 346 shared with Mainland China that were also observed in Australia and Canada, i.e., CCCTGCCCACAGGCGGG 347 amd CCCCGCCCACAGGTGGG. It may be the case though that these subtypes would have been observed early on 348 in the Netherlands and Spain as well, but were missed because sequencing only began with later cases. As 349 expected, however, especially initially but throughout, the predominant subtypes in Italy discussed above,

TCGTCCACGGGTAAC and TCGTCCACGGGTGGG, are represented among viral sequences in all three countries. But 351 distinct subtypes are found in these countries as well. The CCCCTCTCACAGTTGGG subtype has emerged as a 352 highly abundant subtype in United Kingdom data. This subtype has also been found in substantial numbers 353 in the Netherlands, as well as in Australia, but not in Spain. As Figure 13 shows, in Spain, the 354 CCCCTCTCACAGTTGGG subtype was also found in an early sequence data but not thereafter. And, in Spain, a 355 unique subtype has emerged that is not found in abundance in any other country.

Our pipeline also includes the generation of plots that show how the dynamics of a subset evolve over time in 358 different geographical regions. We illustrate this analysis by tracing the progress of the subtype associated 359 with the ISM obtained from the reference viral sequence [34] . Since this sequence appears to have arisen 360 early in the international spread of the virus, it is a useful demonstration for this kind of comparative 361 temporal analysis. This plot illustrates how the reference subtype, which was characterized in early 362 sequences has progressed from being found entirely in Mainland China to being found in the United States, 363
body_text.section: Temporal dynamics of individual viral subtypes across different regions 357

body_text.text: and then subsequently to a greater degree in Europe. is simply being missed. In those cases, it appears from Figures 8, 11 , and 12 that in later times, other 371 subtypes have emerged over time and are becoming increasingly abundant. One potential explanation is that 372 because the SARS-CoV-2, is an RNA virus and thus highly susceptible to mutation as transmissions 373 occur [19] . Therefore, as transmissions have continued, the ISM associated with the reference sequence has 374 been replaced by different ISMs due to these mutations. Another plausible explanation for such leveling off 375 in a region is that the leveling off in relative abundance of the subtype represents containment of that 376 subtype's transmission while other subtypes continue to expand in that country or region. The latter could 377 plausibly explain the pattern observed in the United States, where earlier subtypes connected to Asia did not 378 increase in abundance while a putative endogenous subtype, as well as the dominant New York subtype, have 379 significantly increased in abundance (see Figure 8 and accompanying discussion above). Further investigation 380 and modeling of subtype distributions, as well as additional data, will be necessary to help resolve these All the inferences from the temporal trends in subtypes described in the foregoing, however, must be 383 limited by important caveats: Because the number of viral sequences is much smaller than the number of 384 cases, there may be a lag before a sample is sequenced that includes a particular ISM. As a result, even 385 though subtype CCCTGCCTGTAGGCGGG is first seen in the United States on February 20, 2020 and then a 386 sequence with that ISM was obtained in Canada sequences about 14 days later, that does not necessarily 387 mean that Canada acquired this subtype from the United States. While the presence or absence of this 388 subtype in sequences obtained from travelers may shed light on this question, it cannot be definitive because 389 so few cases due to travel have been sequenced. However, given the amount of time that has lapsed, the 390 general result that this subtype did not originate in Mainland China, for example, is more robust.
body_text.section: Temporal dynamics of individual viral subtypes across different regions 357

body_text.text: Our approach, like all sequence-based interpretation of the COVID-19 pandemic, is further limited in that 392 the depth of sequencing within different regions is highly variable. As an extreme case, Iceland, which has a 393 small population, represents nearly 9% of all sequences in the complete data set. Italy, on the other hand, 394 had a large and early outbreak but has disproportionately less sequencing coverage. As a result, tracking the 395 relative abundances of subtypes across different regions is complicated, because a region that does more 396 sequencing may simply end up having a greater number of sequences of any given subtype. This problem is 397 exacerbated in temporal analysis, because the extent of sequencing efforts in a region may also change over 398 time. Some ISMs also include gaps and ambiguity, which indicate the presence of noise in some sequence 399 data. For example, subtype TCTCGTCCACGGGNNNN could in fact be subtype TCTCGTCCACGGGTAAC and subtype 400 TCTCGTCCACGGGTGGG. We are currently developing methodologies to improve the precision of ISM definition 401 by accounting for technical sequencing errors and ambiguous base calls. We are also evaluating the potential 402 to use epidemiological data for the growth in the number of cases, as a potential supplement for effectively 403 calibrating temporal analysis of viral subtype dynamics.

Temporal trends in growing diversity of ISM subtypes and clustering of related 405 ISM subtypes 406 While keeping in mind the foregoing limitations on the data and our analysis, we do observe that tracking 407 ISM based on the reported date of sequences does reflect the dynamics of the progress of SARS-CoV-2. This 408 is evinced by the results discussed above, which show that the spatiotemporal trends of ISMs are consistent 409 with our general understanding of how the virus has spread, as well as sequence data from travel cases.

probability of changes to the sequence that will lead to a different ISM will increase. To evaluate the increase in ISM diversity, we computed the Hamming distance between each of the 50 414 most prevalent ISMs and the ISM of the reference sequence [12] . These distances, although naïve as they are 415 based on an equally probably nucleotide changes, provide a rough measure of how much each ISM has 416 changed relative to the reference. We then plotted the distance of each ISM along the dates of the first 417 sequence in which the ISM was first detected. As Figure 15 illustrates, even though there is significant 418 variability in this rough measure of the difference between ISMs, there is a clearly accelerating trend towards 419 greater differences over time based on the sequence dates. This provides additional confidence in the 420 robustness of subtyping by ISM according to sequence date. By way of further illustrating this point, Figure 421 15 superimposes the cumulative reported number of confirmed COVID-19 cases over time. 4 While these data 422 provide only a limted picture of the actual number of SARS-CoV-2 infections (including because of limited 423 testing), it further demonstrates that ISM subtypes following sequence dates are capable of tracking the 424 actual temporal progress of the virus.

As the growing diversity shown in Figure 15 illustrates, the number of ISMs is increasing, thus motivating 426 the development of methods to group and organize ISMs into different levels of subtyping. As an initial 427 4 The cumulative reported Worldwide cases were obtained from the Our World In Data Project, which reported them from the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control, made available at https://ourworldindata.org/ coronavirus-source-data.

. CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license author/funder. It is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.07.030759 doi: bioRxiv preprint illustration of this approach, the tree shown in Figure 16 illustrates relationships between geographical and 428 temporal subtypes, which suggests that subtyping can be done using "consensus ISMs" that include common 429 subunits of ISMs beneath them in the hierarchy. For example, the green-colored subtree (labeled A in Figure 430 16 contains the subtypes that are close to the reference sequence ISM subtype (CCCCGCCCACAGGTGGG). Other 431 subtypes in this subtree are also found in Asia, as well as in other countries with links to travel exposure.

The red-colored subtree (labeled B) includes a cluster of subtypes that first were observed in the United 433 States, including the endogenous U.S. subtype described above, CCCTGCCTGTAGGCGGG. (This subtype is 434 labeled as being first observed in Canada, though that first sequence was found from a case linked to U.S. In this paper, we propose to use short sets of nucleotides as markers to define subtypes of SARS-CoV-2 447 sequences (ISMs). We validate the utility of ISM distributions as a complement to phylogenetic tree-based 448 approaches, e.g. as used in the Nextstrain project and by other investigators, by demonstrating that patterns 449 of ISM-based subtypes similarly model the general understanding of how the outbreak has progressed Overall, the entropy-based subtyping approach described in this paper represents a potentially efficient 459 way for researchers to gain further insight on the evolution and diversity of SARS-CoV-2 sequences and their 460 diversity over time. An important caveat of this approach, as with others based on analysis of viral genome 461 sequence, is that it is limited by the sampling of viral sequences. Small and non-uniform samples of 462 sequences may not accurately reflect the true diversity of viral subtypes within a given population. However, 463 the ISM-based approach has the advantage of being scalable as sequence information grows, and as a result 464 will be able to become both more accurate and precise as sequence information grows within different 465 geographical and other subpopulations. Indeed, with the pipeline in place and access to continuously 466 updating sequencing data, ISMs may be continuously identified as new sequences are sequenced and 467 categorized to a subtype for further analysis. In the future, therefore, as data becomes available, ISM-based 468 subtyping may be employed on subpopulations within regions, demographic groups, and groups of patients 469 with different clinical outcome. Efficient subtyping of the massive amount of SARS-CoV-2 sequence data will 470 therefore enable quantitative modeling and machine learning methods to develop improved containment and 471 potentially also therapeutic strategies against SARS-CoV-2. The framework developed here for SARS-CoV-2 472 is applicable to other viruses and, therefore, can be utilized for efficient subtyping and real-time tracking of 473 potential viral pandemics that may emerge in the future as well.

We downloaded all SARS-Cov-2 sequences available from and acknowledge the contributions of the Global 476 Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data (GISAID) EpiFlu database, which has made accessible novel 477 coronavirus sequencing data, including from the NIH Genbank resource [26] . This work was partially 478 supported by NSF grant #1919691. This work also used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery 479 Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number #ACI-1548562.

FIGREF2.text: Overall entropy as a function of nucleotide position for all SARS-CoV-2 sequences in the data setFigure 2shows the overall entropy at each nucleotide position, determined based on calculating the masked entropy for all sequences as described in the Methods section. Notably, at the beginning and the end 124 of the sequence, there is high level of uncertainty. This is because there are more n andsymbols,125    representing ambiguity and gaps, in these two regions (Gaps are likely a result of artifacts in MAFFT's 126 alignment of the viruses or its genomic rearrangement[13], and both N's and -'s may result due to the 127 difficulty of accurately sequencing the genome at the ends). After applying filtering to remove low entropy 128 positions and uncertain positions, we identified 17 informative nucleotide positions on the sequence to 129 generate informative subtype markers (see filtering details in Methods section).

However, as described 146 above, at the present time the high-entropy nucleotide sequences appear to be primarily in open reading 147 frame regions that, at least in comparison to other SARS-related viruses, do not represent areas in which 148

As shown therein, the ISMs are able to successfully 183 identify and label viral subtypes that produce distinct patterns of distribution in different countries/regions. 184 Beginning with Mainland China, the consensus source of SARS-CoV-2, we observe three dominant subtypes 185 in Mainland China, as indicated by relative abundance of the ISM among available sequences: 186 CCCCGCCCACAGGTGGG (as indicated on the plot, first seen in December 24, 2019 in sequences from Mainland 187

For example, one of the most prevalent subtypes in sequences 219

Subtypes with less than 5% abundance are plotted as Other. FIGREF9.text: visualization of commonalities between the subregional subtypes in the United States and the subtypes 232 distributed in other regions. As expected, the viral subtypes on the Diamond Princess cruise ship are the 233 same as those found in Mainland China early in the progress of the virus, which is consistent with the 234 hypothesis of an outbreak resulting from an early exposure by a single source linked to China. In the United 235

FIGREF10.text: 240CCCTGCCTGTAGGCGGG, is also the most abundant in the United States as a whole, likely as the result of 241 Washington state having the most subtypes overall. The same CCCTGCCTGTAGGCGGG subtype is also found in 242 substantial abundance in Canada as well. Consistent with the hypothesis that this subtype is endogenous to 243 the US, the ISM was found in the sequence of one suspected case of exposure in the United States found in 244Canada and 10 sequences in Iceland associated with suspected exposure in the United States. (One travel 245 case in Iceland was of the TTTCGTCCACGTGTGGG subtype dominant in New York.) But this 246 Washington-dominant ISM has not been detected in sequences from New York, further suggesting that the 247 outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 centered in New York may have distinct characteristics likely due to it arising from 248 import in Europe rather than a connection to other U.S. cases on the West Coast. Interestingly, as shown in 249 this Washington-dominant and suspected-endogenous U.S. subtype has been detected in 250Connecticut, which may suggest that there could be some unsequenced circulating cases of this viral subtype 251 in New York as well.

FIGREF11.text: Relative abundance in other countries of the second-most abundant subtype in Italy, TCGTCCACGGGTAAC (left) and most abundant subtype in Italy TCGTCCACGGGTGGG (right).To further validate the utility of ISMs for subtyping, we focused on the analysis of the geographical

FIGREF12.text: Somewhat surprisingly, though the Italy subtypes were found in other states, only 1 out of the 50 265 sequences from New York in the data set had the same ISM as a dominant subtype in Italy (see266    Supplementary file 2 -ISM abundance table of 5 U.S. states and Diamond Princess). This suggests that 267 the outbreak in New York may not be linked directly to travel exposure directly from Italy, but rather from 268 another location in Europe, with the important caveat that the relatively low number of sequences available 269 from Italy means that potential subtypes may not have been detected there. Indeed, the dominant subtype 270

FIGREF13.text: 277subtype in Italy (TCGTCCACGGGTGGG) is found proportionately much more in France and Spain than the 278 second-most abundant subtype (TCGTCCACGGGTAAC), detected later. Conversely, the second-most abundant 279 subtype is found more uniformly in other countries. These observations give rise to two potential hypotheses 280 for further study: (1) An outbreak centered in Italy moved earlier to France and Spain, and cases elsewhere 281 are connected to a combination of earlier and later exposures. Or, (2) the second-most abundant subtype in 282

FIGREF14.text: of viral subtypes within geographical regions 290 The present-time geographical distributions shown in Figures 4, 5, and 6 suggest that ISM subtyping may 291 identify the temporal trends underlying the expansion of SARS-CoV-2 virus and the COVID-19 pandemic. 292 To demonstrate the feasibility of modeling the temporal dynamics of the virus, we first analyzed the 293 temporal progression of different ISMs on a country-by-country basis. This allows examination of the 294 complex behavior of subtypes as infections expand in each country and the potential influence on regional 295 outbreaks by subtypes imported from other regions. Relative abundance (%) of ISMs in DNA sequences from Australia as sampled over time. We focused our analysis on the temporal dynamics of the viral subtypes in Mainland China, Australia, 297 Canada, the United States, the Netherlands, United Kingdom, and Spain. As Figure 4 shows, Australia and 298 Canada have many different subtypes with similar relative abundance showing a substantial level of 299 geographical diversity in ISMs, and by contrast, the United States and larger European countries have a 300 smaller number of predominant subtypes, which may be due to the relative importance of cases linked to 301 travel exposure and endogenous transmission. We include Mainland China in the analysis, as it was the 302 earliest site of viral detection. Following the methods described in the Methods section, we graph how viral 303 Relative abundance of ISMs in DNA sequences from USA as sampled over time. Relative abundance of ISMs in DNA sequences from Canada as sampled over time. Relative abundance of ISMs in DNA sequences from Mainland China as sampled over time. Relative abundance of ISMs in DNA sequences from the United Kingdom as sampled over time. Relative abundance of ISMs in DNA sequences from the Netherlands as sampled over time.

In the case of Mainland China, that could be due to the substantial reduction in reported 367 numbers of new infections and thus additional sequences being sampled. However, the other countries have 368 continuing increases in reported infection as of the date of the data set, as well as substantially increasing 369 numbers of sequences being sampled -making it less likely that the reference subtype (CCCCGCCCACAGGTGGG) 370

FIGREF18.text: 435exposure.) The red-colored subtree also includes subtypes found in Asia in another subcluster, suggesting the 436 emergence of endogenous U.S. subtypes linked to the original U.S. outbreaks linked to Asia.437 By contrast, the subtree colored dark-yellow (labeled E) shows subtypes first seen in Europe, including 438 the subtype that is dominant in New York state (TTTCGTCCACGTGTGGG). Relatedly, the subtypes labeled C 439 (cyan) and D (purple), which are linked to subtype E, show subtypes linked to exposure in Europe (in the 440 case of subtypes observed in Brazil) and other subtypes emerging in European countries in February and 441 March. Interestingly, the cluster of subtypes labeled E also includes an ISM initially found in the United 442 States, suggesting the potential development additional endogenous U.S. subtypes linked the outbreak 443 originating from Europe. We are currently following up on the proof-of-concept clustering result shown here 444 to develop more sophisticated machine learning approaches to identify patterns in viral subtype distribution. 445 Conclusions 446

Specifically, we show that the 451 distribution of ISMs is an indicator of the geographical distribution of the virus as predicted by the flow of 452 the virus from China, the initial European outbreak in Italy and subsequent development of local subtypes 453 within individual European countries as well as interregional differences in viral outbreaks in the United are presented in this paper: http://github.com/EESI/ISM.

TABREF2.text: Figure 4. Major subtypes in countries/regions with the most sequences (indicating date subtype was first sequenced in that country/region). Subtypes with less than 5% abundance are plotted as "OTHER". The raw counts for all ISMs in each country/region, as well as the date each ISM was first found in a sequence in that country/region, are provided in Supplementary file 1 -ISM abundance table of 16 countries/regions. China in the dataset), CCCTGCCCACAGGCGGG (first seen in January 5, 2020 in sequences from Mainland China 188 in the dataset) and CCCCTCCCACAGGTGGG (first seen in January 18, 2020 in sequences from Mainland China in 189 the dataset). These subtypes are found in other countries/regions, but in distinct patterns, which may likely 190 correspond to different patterns of transmission of the virus. For example, sequences in Japan are dominated 191 by CCCCTCCCACAGGTGGG, the third of the subtypes listed for Mainland China, and first observed in a sequence in Japan on February 10, 2020. However, this subtype is not prevalent in other countries/regions, 193 with limited abundance in Australia, Canada, and Singapore -countries that are likely to have travel links 194 to both Mainland China and Japan. However, in Singapore a major subtype is CCCTGCCCACAGG-GGG , which 195 is very close to subtype which was found in Mainland China (CCCCTCCCACAGGTGGG).Moreover, additional metadata provided for certain sequences for the country of exposure in cases197    involving travelers reveals that in other non-Asian countries, the CCCCTCCCACAGGTGGG subtype was frequently 198 found in travelers from Iran, including multiple sequences from Canada and Australia, as well as sequences 199 from the United States (specifically New York), New Zealand, and France. Given that the subtype was otherwise not abundant in these countries, it suggests that these traces are due to the subtype being 201 prevalent in Iran at the time these travel cases were found. But in the absence of sequence data from Iran, it 202 is not presently possible to confirm that hypothesis. In any event, the analysis shows that the ISM-based subtype patterns in Asian countries/regions are related or shared, though as can be seen, the larger portion 204 of outbreaks Singapore and Japan appear to have drawn from distinct subtypes that were found earlier in Mainland China, potentially leading to the hypothesis that there were multiple distinct travel-related transmissions from China (or potentially from Iran) to both countries by the time of this analysis.The data further indicate that the United States has a distinct pattern of dominant subtypes. In particular the subtype with the highest relative abundance among U.S. sequences is CCCTGCCTGTAGGCGGG, first seen in February 20, 2020. This subtype has also emerged as a major subtype in Canada, with the first 210 sequence being found on March 5, 2020. A different pattern is found among sequences in Europe, in which 211 dominant subtypes tend to be different from those found in most Asian countries/regions. Of particular note 212
